pros: - Great BCBA's to work under who care about the wellbeing of the client - Pay - the kids are amazing - BCBA's want to teach you things and want you to grow - coworkers are cool - for the most part, a good code of ethics which makes it a pretty decent, moral place to work for - management wants to see you grow and will work with your needs for the most part
cons: - sometimes difficult to move up within the company - sometime has workplace gossip - few breaks that are only 7 min long, althogh you can always ask for more

pros: Working with amazing kiddos and staff
cons: Can be hard environment to work in

pros: The staff is really nice
cons: Lunch breaks are spilt into 2 15 minute breaks

pros: Working under some of the most knowledgeable people in the field Training and supervision Great work enviornment amongst most staff when in-clinic
cons: No lunches and rarely getting breaks Lots of problems including ethical issues amongst RBTs and BCBAs get swept under the rug Nonprofit company, so pay rate, breaks, and other important aspects of a good work enviornment are constantly changing Quality of patient care has went down since 2019 Clinical director is hardly present No real opportunity for growth for RBTs Clinic is unsanitary and not a healthy enviornment

review_title: Not as great as they used to be
pros: Set hours Free CEUs Shared offices with other BCBAs for collaboration Access to materials CE Funds Great PTO/Benefits
cons: Scorecard system that is difficult to meet Lack of support from Clinical Directors and above Heavily focused on bill, bill, bill Clinical decision making taken away by senior leadership team of BCBAs Favoritism No consistency across programs, QA measure implemented inconsistently across programs Poorly pays RBTs, high turnover as a result

pros: Overall sense of teamwork, friendly coworkers, can choose part time or full time, and can also choose to be non-benefited (no insurance) for higher hourly pay, if you can prove you have insurance.
cons: Sometimes difficult to get in-the-moment support if there are no open staff, although there have been many recent changes to help with that. Minimal opportunities for promotion, and positions available can be difficult to get. Pay is good for non-benefited, average for people who need insurance.

review_title: Honest review from a long-time employee (Carmel Location)
pros:
- Friendly RBTs, generally a good work environment
- new "mentor" program to help new hires feel comfortable
- overall decent pay ($17/hr, 32 hr guarantee for full-time, $21+ for non-benefitted/flex, but not guaranteed hours)
- flexible if you need a specific schedule to allow for school, although they WILL ask you to transition to full availability when possible
- BCBAs are very supportive in answering questions, providing behavioral support, and supervision hours
- (limited) Lead RBT positions available for an additional $1/hr
- new "in person" 40 hour training being put into place to be more comprehensive for new hires
- online training required occasionally outside of work hours, but will clock in for them
-staff meetings in person once per month (also paid)
- everyone gives shout-outs, and generally pitches in when needed for chores, making materials, etc
cons:
- only two 7-minute breaks, which you do not always get. 
- new policy instated that pays Carmel TABI (Teen and Adult Intervention) therapists $1 more per hour, which seems beneficial to a limited amount of people and unfair to people working in other programs
- high turnover rate; therapy sessions are being cancelled often, meaning parents in general have been upset or more difficult to deal with
- will often have to substitute on patients you have never met or never worked with before, on short notice
(*some of these you will run into at ANY ABA provider, since overall there's a big RBT staffing shortage)
- CEO has sent out emails to parents essentially blaming RBTs for "disloyalty" / staffing shortages, which caused more people to quit and parents to be more hostile to therapists. Has also sent out emails to past employees who are at new organizations, essentially trying to guilt them into returning

review_title: It's an okay place to work.
pros:
-Working with amazing patients
-Working with supportive and really fun staff
-Support during episodes of problem behavior is immediate
-Weekly snacks and drinks
-Food provided for team meetings (cake)
-Punishment Review Board to ensure punishment procedures are ethical
cons:
(lengthy, but informative)

-Understaffing is a HUGE problem
-Policies can be nit-picky
-People are reprimanded for hearsay
-Two "breaks" each day, 7 minutes each
-CA meetings early in the morning, would have preferred that we all vote on a time versus being told what time
-You take a steep pay cut when going in to the CA position, to the tune of $3 plus per hour
-Schedulers not being communicative of last minute changes in the morning

To be fair, the Clinical Apprentice position (assistant to the BCBA) is a great position. And when it works, it works. The caveat to that is you have to have proper staffing for it to work. If there isn't enough staff, you will have to cover therapy up to 40 hours per week. It got so bad that they ended up making a policy to where CAs HAVE to cover at least 16 hours per WEEK, when it used to be that they couldn't pull you onto the floor for more than 16 hours per MONTH. While covering therapy isn't the end of the world, it can become extremely frustrating when you are trying to earn your supervision hours. The board requires that you earn 60% unrestricted (behavior plans, treatment plans, monthly goals, anything BCBAs do, etc.), which you cannot feasibly do if you're on the floor a lot. This also reduces clinical staff support. I appreciate the experience overall, but having to cover therapy so much definitely dampened my experience.

Advice for prospective applicants: If you are looking in to dipping your toes into the field of ABA, this is a standard opportunity to do so. Gain your experience, learn what you need to learn, and then move on honestly.

pros: Amazing staff, good training, good hours, and flexibility.
cons: Challenging work and occasional miscommunications

review_title: Great for those that don't need health insurance
pros: Flexibility with hours and a starting rate of 21/hour for those without benefits
cons: Employees with benefits have a lower wage and still have to pay for insurance through their paycheck. Supervisors can be condescending.

review_title: It's alright, but not the best
pros:
Steady hours, always 8-4 M-F
Nice pay (especially for those without a degree)
Good coworkers, quickly can make friends
Flexibility in selecting hours and type of contract
cons:
No breaks (bathroom break is your break) and no lunch (eat with client)
Management is tough on you and expects a lot right away
Job is demanding emotionally and physically
Some questionable practices come into play

pros: Flexibility, mission statement, paid time off
cons: Cannot think of any cons

review_title: Okay Company But Straying From Values
job_title: Registered Behavior Technician in Carmel, IN
pros: Little Star is a well-organized company, with great intent to serve individuals with autism and their families. Staff is friendly and the kids are a joy to work with. Some leaders/program managers are more hands-on with their training and support than others.
cons: More and more policy-making centered around achieving as many billable hours as possible, rather than achieving client-centered care. Really high expectations of BCBAs. Seem to care more about numbers than quality employees or loyalty. For example, the company recently suspended all seniority raises for RBTs and yet is offering hiring bonuses for brand new RBTs. They reinstated the raises, but the fact that they suspended in the first place shows where their values lie. Education and experience are not as valued as a warm body who can bring in billable hours. High expectations of leadership can promote quality assurance but often come across as very punitive and unsupportive. Many, many rules and policies but little consistency or oversight of said policies. As far as ABA companies, it's pretty average...not terrible, but not a place I feel proud to work at either.

pros: Amazing environment and clinical support. Tons of room for growth
cons: A bit more strict than other places on many things

pros: It’s great and hours are flexible
cons: I’m a shortage because of covid

pros: I like working here, definitely feel like you are making a difference, love the kids we work with. My manager is awesome but I’ve only ever worked with him, I can’t vouch for any of the others. They recently increased the pay which has given them a competitive edge vs other Aba companies in the area
cons: The scheduling really needs some work. They are very unorganized and it can be hard to get time off sometimes. The kiddos can be hard sometimes if you have an aggressive kid, it can make the days really long.

review_title: A Wonderful Company to Work For
pros: Little Star thought of everything. The attention was in the details. Of course they had everything they needed for the learners but they had everything that the therapists needed also. We had a nursing room for the new moms who came back to work who needed to pump, they had a beautiful kitchen, fully stocked with snacks for therapist for our convenience. The adult ladies rooms and men's rooms were stocked with toiletries. The training was top notch and they were always looking for ways to praise team members.
cons: The ABA Apprentice program was brand new when I became an apprentice. It was a wonderful program but again, it was brand new and needed some tweeking.

pros: meeting and discussing cases with the advisory board was a great experience, I wish it occurred more than once a quarter.
cons: during the interview process I was assured that each clinical director is extremely knowledgeable and that I would have access to a BCBA-D whenever needed. This unfortunately was not the case. I went to LittleStar to learn from wonderful BCBAs and unfortunately that was not my experience.

job_title: Board Certified Behavior Analyst Bcba in Danville, VA
pros: Free CEU opportunities, ability to have a flexible schedule, 401K, opportunities for advancement, benefits, ability to receive mentor ship opportunities on cases, performance based incentive bonuses monthly
cons: Infrequent communication issues between scheduling and clinicians

job_title: Child Care Teacher in Karlstad, MN
pros: get to help childern in need
cons: can get very over welming

review_title: During Civid I think they care
pros: During Covid they tried to keep everybody working and safe. I didn’t lose my health insurance or have to take a pay cut. I lost some hours, but that was not LittleStar’s fault. I have friends who work at other ABA centers and LittleStar by far was the most pro-active, safe and organized through it.
cons: Lost some hours, but it was because of the parents cutting back. Will be glad when centers are open fully again.

pros: Working with all the kids can be really rewarding and very fun!
cons: Human Resources and upper management only care about salaried employees and not about their hourly employees. They have suspended pay raises and policies that provided financial security for hourly employees since COVID has started. They care about quantity not quality of employees and only care about how much money they can bring in from insurance billing. For a nonprofit it doesn’t seem to make any sense as to where the money goes if not to it’s hourly employees anymore.

job_title: Respite Care Provider in Bloomington, IN
pros: The administrative staff were highly skilled in communication efficiently and proactively with me as an employee. When I had concerns or unfamiliarity, they provided me with additional training and resources. I felt well respected and acknowledged of my work in such a short time frame.
cons: Some aspects of the job are definitely challenging physical and emotionally, but is not an error of Little Start and is just part of best helping the children.

job_title: Board Certified Behavior Analyst Bcba in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The families, clients, co-workers are helpful.
cons: A lot of work can be thrown at you at once.

job_title: Program Manager Apprentice in Bloomington, IN
pros: High quality BCBA with opportunities for staff development and training. Ongoing RBT supervision to ensure everything is going how it should. Fun atmosphere with a lot of great opportunities for the kids to expand their skills.
cons: Seems to be shifting towards BCBA billing-centered rather than patient-centered goals.

pros: Incentive pay for good work which is very easy to get, hazard pay during the pandemic, tons of support from management and input on patients is taken seriously. Truly care about how the kids are doing and have set goals for them
cons: Changes policies often which can be difficult to keep up with; very limited mileage reimbursement for therapists traveling to patient's homes

review_title: Not a bad place to work
pros:
Pays well with no experience/degree
They train you to become an RBT
cons:
Every Behavior Analyst has a different way they want therapy done
Do not become an RBT if you can't handle dealing with unwanted behaviors

pros:
-fun kiddos
-rewarding
-helps prepare for RBT test
cons:

-Low to average wage
-Inconsistency with staff/program implementation

pros: The learners are the best part of the job
cons: Management does not care about their employees. They continue to take from the core employees.

pros: Good pay and good PTO
cons: Work schedule unreliable at times

pros: Mileage Reimbursement, almost all of my co workers were so awesome!
cons: Management picks favorites and makes jokes to those favorites about firing employees. Alex the BCBA is the worst of all.. BEWARE. If you get on a radar, you will be fired in an instant for the most ridiculous things. If you want to go back to high school, this is the job for you. As a grown adult, it was not for me and most people I worked with left or were fired for the most absurd reasons.

pros: My experience with the staff has been nothing but remarkable. Everyone is always helpful and I feel that they all truly care about each child and their individual needs.
cons: No lunch break or paid sick days allotted.

pros:
This 'job' turned into a career path for many of our employees.  The atmosphere is like walking into a family reunion, EVERYDAY! Greeted with smiling faces, children ready to learn and succeed and upper management who has the utmost care in the world. 
I have never felt so included in a work environment. When family issues occur- the staff is there for you! The staff has come together to raise money for our families, donate food and show real care to one another. Having such enjoyable staff is only PART of why I cannot leave.
Walking in and seeing the kids INSTANTLY turns your day around! The kids value the staff, their time and dedication to this job. Seeing the success in the learners is absolutely life changing. Being a part of the success and helping the families makes every challenge or struggle 150% worth it! 
The families at this center are so invested and in tune with the staff. The families are so connected with the RBTs and get to know them which makes us (the staff) feel even more apart of these kids lives. 
This company truly shows care, advocacy and progress. LittleStar ABA pushes therapists to study and receive a well known certification as an RBT. This company is so invested in their staff that they are always completing training to keep everyone up to date on research and  on top of their A+ game! LittleStar is truly a home away from home!
cons: We have too much fun, it's hard to focus :)

pros: Good pay and benefit options
cons:
lots of drama
if they don't like you, you won't be employed long

pros: Care is individualized to clients.
cons: When COVID-19 hit, unfair hours were given.

review_title: This is a solid ABA organization!
pros:
Company is based in ABA and doesn't promote non-evidence based treatments
Little Star is a not for profit and gives back to the community
Performance based pay is good for people like me, but not for people who are not hard workers or who are not focused on their learner.
Management is nice and if you make an effort to get to know them, they will be very open with you. I have worked here for 4 years.
Free coffee, soda, candy and snacks provided!
My Program Manager teaches me a lot about ABA.
cons:
Some companies pay more, I have worked for 2 others, but they are not 100% ABA and I felt like more of a baby-sitter there.
If you like to goof off, this is not the place, because they have a lot of supervisors
401K match was suspended for a while

review_title: Do not work here or take your child here

review_title: In every job that must be done there is an element of fun!
pros:
- A culture that encourages brainstorming, collaboration, feedback, and always having fun!
-Family atmosphere 
-Learners are making real progress everyday!
-Company advocates for individuals with autism across the country.
-Learners always come first! Learners are provided the services that the BCBA prescribed even if insurance is cut. Services are provided in all settings. 
-Insurance department assists in getting services covered and paid for. 
-4 Free CEU opportunities a month plus money to spend on professional development for BCBAs.
- RBT training, test, and credential is paid for.
-The company is able to make difficult decisions in order to continue providing high quality services. 
- The company has multiple focus groups where staff at all levels can be heard and changes are made accordingly.
-I laugh everyday with the learners and with my coworkers!
cons: This can be a difficult and high stress job but I feel supported and appreciated.

pros:
Insurance benefits immediate.
Good starting pay
You make a difference in a kids life
Not really much else that’s great about this place
No  room for advancements unless you want to go back to school
cons: Terrible upper management. Clinical directors do not care about truly knowing your progress as an RBT especially in the upper programs. They treat you terribly and then after they poorly treated you they will fire you on the spot without a progression of warnings. The company also treats employees poorly with no breaks or lunch hour. It’s a stressful job.

pros: Very rewarding job, great pay, Christmas break, Monday thru Friday job with weekends off, first shift, you do not take your work home, chance to move up in management
cons: No scheduled breaks, you must eat lunch with your learner, you can some times be with a clent for a very long time and become easily burnt out, some favoritism

job_title: ABA Therapist (In Center and In Home) in Carmel, IN
pros: Little star center does a good job training in aba therapy and calm.
cons: They have a terrible high school click atmosphere.  The 3 centers in carmel; little star, middle star, and elp; spend more time being petty and not communicating then they do worrying about how to staff their kiddos well.  Little Star also puts money above their therapists' safety which is a big concern.

review_title: Love the job. Less impressed with the leadership team.
pros: Working as an ABA therapist for this company is so rewarding. The clients, families, and staff I work with are all wonderful.
cons: A lot of the time the staff at Little Star does not feel heard or valued by the leadership team and Human Resources. During this Pandemic it seemed like they have tried slightly more to be accommodating, but ultimately there is still a lot of work that can be done.
